commentBody:
The link is not working from the puzzle page and there is no listing on the main Gameplay page for the column either. 

I found it by searching “Sam Corbin”, but I doubt many readers will think to do that.

The front door wasn't open, 
so I had to sneak into 
the comments cave 
under a sheep. 

How did ewe get here?

I hope the ayes have this one.

Thank you, Joseph.

I had not noticed, until I got down to 73A, that there were no I's in the clues, either. I frequently miss things like that. I'm curious, though, why the clue adds "when sounded out." This would seem to be unnecessary? Whether you read it silently or aloud, it says ONE EYE. Maybe I'm missing something obvious, which I frequently also do. (And if I were sounding out the letters ONEEYE without knowing what they meant, I wouldn't be pronouncing them ONE EYE). But I enjoyed the puzzle.

I (haha) LOVED this puzzle. Quick and clever fill, and for Greek mythology fans like myself, it's just a really enjoyable solve. I especially enjoyed COCOON and EDEN. As I was solving, I had the thought that STRUM is usually clued with a guitar, not a ukulele- now it makes sense! Avoiding "i"s at all costs!!

Polyphemus was not "the" cyclops, he was one of many cyclopes.  But he probably did yell something like "I can't see" when he was poked in the eye by No Man/wily Odysseus.  Too bad the constructor couldn't get that one "I" into "Poseidon," Polyphemus' father.

You know it's a good puzzle when you can suss out and learn a new words by slowly figuring out the crosses. Many smart clues, or maybe I'm just on the same wavelength as the constructor. Would have been cool to have seen NOBODY in there too? :)

Sam Corbin:  18A.  “Cry after a poke” seems to be a reference to what one would say after being poked in the eye, similar to what happened to Polyphemus in The Odyssey - it isn’t a reference to poking someone to get a better view.

A man with a singular vision, and it had to be all about me, no, scratch that, about "I". And, of course, the puzzle was all about "I", since it was in the center and the rest was all around it. I very nice exercise, excising all but the one "I" while reaching back to theme the puzzle on a traveler's adventures on an island.

Lots of fun, thanks, Joseph!
Kudos!  What a delightful puzzle!   Very clever clues, and an unusual theme.  Well done!
I guess I'm showing my age. I assumed that "I can't see" as the response to a poke was a reference to Moe's eye gouging antics in the old Three Stooges films.

A fun challenge for a Wednesday.   Glad I read the Odyessy when I was young and the details stuck.   Also, Greece has been on my mind recently,  because a friend who knows I've been a few times is thinking of going and asked me what they should do/see.

I did not know that doing math in your head had a name. 

On another topic, I may be in trouble with Wyna taking over the mini. Today was almost a DNF (did not finish).  Did not know the Chinese greeting and kept wanting Best in Show to be about the Christopher Guest movie.

18A isn’t ambiguous—it’s another reference to this puzzle’s theme. Odysseus famously defeated the cyclops by gouging (or “poking”) out its eye, and since the creature only had the one, it was blinded. It’s no coincidence that this answer begins with the one, circled “I” in this puzzle.

Such a delightful puzzle.

I enjoyed every minute of it and must have been on Mr. Gangis's wavelength (though Greek mythology is not my forté and has never captivated me.) 

I had to therefore get POLYPHEMUS from the crosses, especially because I really wanted it to be a geometry clue just so I could put in POLYHEDRON.  

Favorite clue? Definitely "Wrap for a monarch." 
It inspired thoughts of the safety of the COCOON created by a warm comforter, as well as the beautiful vision of all things that FLAP their wings and fly free.

Thank you for this delicious puzzle, Mr. Gangis. 
EYE've had a wonderful time.
Puzzlingly, I was all alone

All that Greek and Roman mythology I learned as a kid, sure comes in handy when solving crosswords.  I’m constantly amazed at how much of it I’ve retained, although several trips to many of the great museums of Europe with my art conservator daughter, probably helped reinforce that early learning.  All that is by way of saying that today’s delightful puzzle was well within my wheelhouse.  The puzzle was nicely constructed and had some nice little bonuses tucked in.  Bravo!
Really fun puzzle,  loved the classical theme.

Very fun puzzle!  

Thank you, Joseph Gangi!  (Your name has "one 'i'!)
That was fun. Given the constructor's self-imposed "one I" grid restriction and creative theme I won't even complain about the Oreo.

Hebrew alphabet is really tough for me. And didn’t recall the cyclops being POLYPHEMUS. 

So, on my ODYSSEY home, I WANDERED around Natick for quite a while.

Fun puzzle. Go warriors.
Being a fan of Homer's Odyssey, I blew through this puzzle like the bag of winds gifted by King Aeolus.

Understood the revealer wrongly.
Returned to clues and reread them all, to locate the one clue that had the, you know, eye.
Was sure there would be another clever reference to Ulysses concealed that way.
Nope, just can’t read.

But bonus: composed my comment based on the theme. A tad hard to eschew that one letter.
Here are two question for Classical fans: from beginning to end, approximately how much time passes between the first and last books of The Odyssey? Same question for The Iliad.
Loved the puzzle, it was fun.  THANKS
A monarch doesn’t pupate in a cocoon, but in a chrysalis. Moths pupate in cocoons and monarchs are butterflies.
This theme reminds me of the song by The Shirrells, “This is dedicated to the one I love.”  I’ve always called it “The Cyclops love song.”

As a teacher and frequent reader of The Very Hungry Caterpillar I am always sure to point this out to my students that butterflies create chrysalises, not cocoons (as Mr. Carle erroneously writes). 

When I saw the clue at 70A I had a tiny spark of hope that maybe there was some other clever entry that I hadn’t figured out yet. But alas, it was not to be! I am gratified to see other puzzle goers noting this error and I suppose, as lauded as they are, the puzzle editors are only human and may be afforded a mistake here and there. 

This oversight aside however, this was a clever puzzle that I quite enjoyed. It seemed a tad easier than a typical Wednesday but I think it’s just that solving flowed more me and I didn’t get stuck in any particular spot. Extra kudos for the volume of work I’m sure it took to ensure there really was only the one ‘i’.
Not too easy - perfect Wednesday puzzle. Brilliant effort - gave me a good laugh when completed. Thank you for the entertainment!

I was stuck on troglodytes for the "cave dweller" clue.  If you hadn't given it to us Sam, I'd still be struggling. I was unable to get Polyphemus with crossings unfortunately. A name I either never knew, or forgot 60 years ago when I read the Odyssey.  Once I plugged it in, I finished the puzzle without problem.  I knew Sasha was correct, so was sure my troglodyte was wrong. (I even googled "are there any other skaters named Cohen except Sasha?") I'm so bad. Wednesdays are my favorite puzzle day. So this hump day, I had to climb over a huge hump.  I'll be looking up Polyphemus so I don't forget for next time.  The rest of the puzzle clues were fun. Thank you NYT.

“presumably the poker is the one who needs a better sightline.”

No! The poker is the one who poked 20A in the 73A !

I find it a bit funny that some posters complain about POLYPHEMUS being too niche, even esoteric. He's part of one of Europe's oldest and best known stories, one at the foundations of a shared European and American heritage. I found the whole theme a gimme, which was a nice surprise in a puzzle which otherwise required me to know some wrestler and a regional brand.
Any other Texas children of the early 1960s out there who had trouble letting go of jelloSALAD ? Just me ?

One of my most fun AHA moments when I caught on to how the theme worked.  Very impressive construction.  

Thanks, Joseph for my favorite Wednesday puzzle for a long time.  ( maybe for ever)
Yay! What a delight. Thanks Joseph. And shout-out to the editors for the clue to 21D.

Well *I* thought today’s a great crossword, thank you Joseph! Those old Greek legends are far from my forte, but nonetheless no horsefeathers for me and managed to complete the puzzle ASAP. 

And gosh just to create one comment sans *that* letter—the forsaken “eye”—be a heck of a challenge! Well done on an entire puzzle!

Well - looks like the ayes have it* today. I'll join the chorus. The usual long workout for me, but that was just one amazing feat of construction. Had to go and review it all after I was done and was just stunned to finally see what was going on. Wow. Just wow. 

*A couple of remarkable puzzle finds today. I'll put those in a reply. 

..

I was floored by this immensely clever puzzle theme! Others have already pointed out that “I CAN’T SEE” at 18A is a reference to 20A’s cry when Odysseus 7Ds him… what an excellent cluster of crossings. 

I’ve felt like lately, the great theme ideas have been somewhat spoiled by mediocre and gluey fill in the rest of the grid. Not this one! The smooth solve was a lovely start to my Wednesday.

I won.

Or, rather, completed the puzzle.

Impressive puzzle, demonstrating selfless commitment to the craft.

Saw the clue, hoped…hoped…
could it be..? On a Wednesday?

POLYTHEMUS!!

Memories of freshman year of high school…

Siren song…calling himself Noman…

“Who did this to you?”
“ Noman did this!”

Sneaky devil…

(I’m certain I’ve remembered most of this inaccurately, but my eyes are barely open and I don’t care. It was 40 years ago.)

Brilliant and fun puzzle.
With one 👁️.

Loved it.

I rarely comment, but as a former Classics student this made my day when I spotted the theme. I had to dig a bit deeper to recall the proper spelling of POLYPHEMUS, but after that it was smooth sailing (unlike what the unlucky Odysseus got!)

I appreciated WANDERED, ORAL, MAIM and PLOY as additional nods to the Homeric theme. Couldn't help wishing that STRUM had been clued using the classical Greek lyre, but possibly that was a step too far - and I'm not completely sure that's the correct verb for a lyre.

Great fun!

What's that feeling called when you are pulled away from the grid and later you realize, "did I click pause or not?"

Yes, it's a Wednesday. Got a bit flustered working the across clues. Plugged in "ueey"  for 63D and the penny dropped, so to speak. 

Great puzzle!

First of all, this is Joseph’s third NYT puzzle, and the grid art of his first – well, it may be the cutest looking puzzle of all time. You are missing a heart-warming moment if you skip over this: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2022/03/16 . On this puzzle, I love how Joseph placed that one circle close to the top of the grid. It could have helped to reveal the puzzle’s gimmick, but for me, at least, I was so engrossed in the rest of the puzzle, that when I got down to the bottom, where the reveal was, I had totally forgotten that circle. So, when I uncovered ONE EYE and saw what was going on, and saw that circle again, it was a fantastic “Oh yeah, I forgot about that!” moment. Joseph got me good there, and I love being gotten good! Also, I don’t think anyone so far has mentioned that they noticed anything unusual in the cluing until it was pointed out in the revealer, certainly not I. Bravo to Joseph for pulling that off, depriving the clues of a common vowel – and have no one notice it. He got me good there again. One more way he fooled me. I tooled through the puzzle thinking that it was simply a myth-based tribute, with no thought that there was an underlying gimmick. So, when I uncovered the ONE EYE reveal, oh, trust me, that elicited a huge “Hah!” As I said, Joseph, I love being gotten good, and to be gotten good three times, well, three’s the charm. Many many thanks for this!

The Classics nerd in me made this puzzle a walk on the beach, although it also briefly renamed Ms. Cohen "Easha," as I wanted to have FLORAe in my garden. There were, in fact a whole race of cyclopses: the patriarchs of the clan were three brothers, sons of Uranus and Gaia, Brontes, Steropes, and Arges by name. They forged the first thunderbolts for Zeus, although later, in a hostile takeover, ownership of the company passed to Hephestos, and they became mere employees. That their race continued meant that there were also cycloptettes, although, like where Cain got his wife, this is never explained. Here's Handel's musical take on the whole situation, OBOEs and all--Polyphemos himself doesn't appear until 1'50'': https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=arBNPhF3QE0. And here's the Man of the Hour himself--who knew he could play the flute so well?: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4K4EMHnlWCo (Sorry for the static videos, the live action ones weren't all that good.) The circle around the "I", Mr. Gangi, was overkill, but etymologically a nice touch.
Wow, how cool! My mythology isn’t what it could be so this sent me down a rabbithole of looking up the Cyclops tale. What I learned from a crossword today!

A challenging puzzle—I finished around a minute over my average—but nonetheless I found it delightful; like at least one other solver, it  took me to my freshman year of high school when I had to read The Odyssey, which I initially faced with dread but came to love before I finished. It’s stunning how a single word…POLYPHEMUS…can carry one back nearly 60 years. More recently I’ve read the Emily Wilson translation, which I recommend…including her long (90-page) introduction.

Once again, editors, please quit poking Classics (Latin and Greek) majors in the eye with the capital ETA. Yes, it looks like a Roman H, but why not call it E to Homer (or whomever). I've had modern Greek speakers tell me that both epsilon and eta are sounded like the "ee" in "week." It is high time to change this frequent fill from appearance to sound, as in this puzzle did with the I / eye. Thank you.
A watermelon is shaped like an OVOID. The only reason I know that is because of the New York Times Crossword. Be better!

A truly horrific Homeric episode. The wee pup BB is torn between the son of Poseidon (Polyphemus) and the polytropus "No Man." "What would you do, if you were about to have your bashed in, be roasted and eaten," asks her human. But BB is also concerned about her fellow earthlings, the sheep, who sacrificed themselves for the crew's escape. Not to mention, that so-called "poke in the eye" was more along the lines of a savage blinding stab. Get me to the gentle love nest of Kirke, at least for a time. Penelope awaits, my faithful gal.

Another fun puzzle. Thanks, team!

In Joyce’s Ulysses, the cyclops is recast as “the citizen,” a freeloader cadging drinks at a pub visited by an unnamed narrator and his friend (later Bloom - Ulysses - wanders in.)  Yes, the citizen has a dog.  The entire chapter is gut splitting hilarious, capped by the now drunken citizen throwing an empty sardine can at Bloom as he leaves the bar.
I liked this enjoyable crossword. "I" thought it was clever. Love Polyphemus moths ~ they're so beautiful.
Really enjoyed the theme to this one. Especially 18A

Good morning! Still having my coffee. You'd think my 5-mile walk would have woken me up.
On my first pass through, I had IKEA, which I vaguely knew was wrong, insted of LEGO; ELIZA for "Beth preceder" - which I though was kind of fun;  FAIR instead of MERE for "Just". 
It all came together, and now...yeah, still not awake. But I'd better get to working. Have a good day.

I confess I didn’t know the correct name for Mr ONE EYE, so had to battle the crosses. ALEPH got me good, I had Eliza for too long. Stuck with LEVEL I also. Hence it was a bit of a crawl for me today. 

Very impressed with the finished grid. It wasn’t until I went back to admire it that I fully realised the importance of that circled I.  Wow.

Cute theme and fun solve, but…

THERE IS NO B STREET IN DC! Not unless you have a time machine. The Bs were renamed Constitution and Independence in the 1930s. I believe this is the second time I’ve seen this error in a NYT crossword. It’s starting to feel like a deliberate snub. ;-)
Monarch pupae are not wrapped in a COCOON... rather, a chrysalis. Moths have coccons, not butterflies.

I'd say you hit a Homer this time, Mr. Gangi.  A fun puzzle and a miracle of construction.  (Eye can't say enough about that!)  It was a pleasure to spend the evening sailing around the Aegean in some classic company, but I'm aware that what you did may have been more challenging than what we did.  Either way, I'm looking forward to more of your puzzles.

Thank you!

Gonna have to give this puzzle a big fail. POLYPHEMUS is far too esoteric of a word to be used without suitable crossings.  In this case, I finished the puzzle with an internally consistent answer schema minus POLYPHEMUS, namely

PATH
A
I
N
NEMUS

Mental PATH and PAIN both satisfactory answered the clues. If you're going to have a theme like this, use better crossings

This was fun! First time ever hearing of POLYPHEMUS.

An OBOE isn’t really an orchestra “part,” though, is it? “Part” more accurately refers to the individual instruments’ sheet music extrapolated from a larger (orchestral) score.

Absolutely loved this one!  When I first saw 20A's clue, I immediately thought it had to be the cyclops and was disappointed that the letters just didn't work, only to be delighted when I realized I was right later on. Can't say I remember hearing the name "Polyphemus" before, but luckily I knew enough from the other clues to work this one out.
Usually Wednesdays are when I sometimes have maybe 3 or four clues I just can't get or start to need help, but this one was really on my wavelength. Not only did I keep up my streak from the past two days, and got it in 12:40, 20 minutes faster than my average Wednesday crossword.

Is that Ms Gorski on the bench?

Baader-Meinhof is a revolutionary group from Germany,,, everyone knows that.  POKE POKE this is a joke no need to send corrections.

Lovely Wednesday.  Thank you, Joseph.

Couldn't immediately remember POLYPHEMUS so it took me a bit to catch on to the theme. Happily I didn't come across the revealer -- or figure out THE CYCLOPS -- until I was probably 2/3 done, and genuinely laughed out loud. The lone "I" being the start of I CAN'T SEE following a singular poke was the cherry on top of an already very clever puzzle.

Loved this! Favorite puzzle in a while!
While as Sam Corbin notes, there are several possible answers for 18A (“Cry after a poke”), I appreciated how the actual answer fit so nicely with today’s theme.

"Beth" is an unnecessarily obscure clue for Aleph. Unless you're a Semitic language scholar, you have no chance with this one. I'm not a crossword constructor so what would I know, but this just seems weak to me.

Just slightly off the right wavelength today - got stuck with level I instead of levela a, tires / taxes, stop / a top (I thought I was rather clever with stop being for over) - and more ...

Liked the theme, I would think an errant poke to a cyclopes could likely result in I CAN'T SEE. 

I find it a little funny the detail they give in some clues versus others  - they give us the game 'chess castle' for rook yet when it comes to 'Beth Preceder' we are somehow to surmise it's the Hebrew alphabet. I propose give us 'castle' and 'Beth Preceder letter' - I still wouldn't get it but would feel a little more doable.

Alternate cluing for 18A:

"Words uttered by 20-Across, maybe"

Alternate cluing for 65A:

"How the hero of 41-Across got home"
Lots of fun. The classical theme was certainly a nice change from the usual parade of pop culture pseudo-celebrities. More like this, please.

Despite starting the day quite early (weeding) my volunteer assignment means I don't have time to check through 99 Comments  to see if anyone else has the same take, so:
The 73A clue (Reveal) is unnecessarly complicated.  "When sounded out?"  What's to "sound out?"  There is no mystery.  Just read it (silently is fine.)  Both POLYPHEMUS and the puzzle have but ONE EYE/i.  Big whoop (as in, no surprise, given the prominent circle at Square 18.)  
Ulysses certainly left a trail of destruction on his lengthy ODYSSEY, eh?  65A's clue and entry were quite apt, although we can't help noticing that a certain someone's dalliance created unnecessary delay.  

On with the day!
Very enjoyable puzzle!

Easier Wednesday than most... but (hangs head) I had to look up the name of "cave dweller of Greek myth."
The fill was good enough to lead me to CYCLOPS (and of course ONE EYE followed).
Neat that the one circled "I" was apparently the only one in the puzzle!!!!
This must have been a difficult construction!?!
Thank you, Joseph Gangi!

Tougher than usual Wednesday for me, which is always a good thing.  I didn't know POLYPHEMUS and did not know the skater.  Actually, SASHA immediately popped into my head, but I thought I was mixing the skater up with SAcHA BARON COHEN, so I didn't put it in right away.  I also had ark instead of POD at 11A, so 13D just had to be kEEn, right?  I did get it sorted out, but my time was a little longer than most recent Wednesday's.

The missing "I" part of the theme was very impressive.  At no time did I find the clues forced, which I would expect given the constraint.  You did a great job, Joseph.  This is a puzzle to be proud of.
Impressive…and fun!

I had an eye pun all ready. Iris I could wink of it.

(Maybe this teacher will ask his pupils.)
There is an inaccuracy in clue 70a for today's puzzle. Butterflies like the monarch form a chrysalis for their transformation. Cocoons are made only by moths!
Eye was very impressed!
18A reminded me of the old three stooges routine: https://youtu.be/eeLKdrh0KAQ?si=8cJtpDPgw3yEyBTL
One Eye, very clever. Bravo!
Delightful!
Clever and fun.
Really fun!

Very subtle trick.

Blink and you myth it.

.
Great puzzle!
11D also appears in today’s New Yorker crossword, 57A, as does most of the 11D clue itself, 41A.  Coincidence?!?  The constructor, Robyn Weintraub, is of course an NYT frequent favorite.

I love the Greek myths. My wife and I both went to a liberal arts college where I studied physics and history, and she studied chemistry and Greece.  We bonded over poking each other's eye out and running away on the bottom of a sheep.

Loved this theme! My one gripe with this puzzle is 70A... chrysalises (like monarchs create) and cocoons  (created by moths) are distinct things! They happen at different developmental stages, and aren't interchangeable.
Great puzzle! Loved it, thank you for the fun and edifying Wednesday solve.

I preferred his
"first submission of this puzzle had the lone “I” in an unchecked square surrounded with black squares (giving a visual representation of an eye."
Egad
That would have been wonderful!

What I particularly enjoyed about the clue about the poke is that if you only have one eye, one poke means “I can’t see!” Which brings yet another level to the overall theme.  This was a joy to solve.

I teach at a school whose mascot is the Monarchs.  As every student in the school knows, a Monarch butterfly does not "wrap" in a cocoon.  A Monarch is wrapped in a chrysalis.  Moths grow up in cocoons.
At no point in this puzzle did I find myself caught between Scylla and Charybdis. (No mental arithmetic required.)

In a reply on an early thread an hour ago, Yak (from Oak Park IL) mentioned a butterfly that *does* emerge from a COCOON. I looked it up, and found: "Unlike most butterflies that have exposed pupae, they pupate inside a loose silken cocoon." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parnassius Who gnu? Not eye!
brilliant puzzle - top notch effort. bravo!! finally... 4 years of latin in HS pays off LOL

Some thoughts: 
3d: Having grown up where almost every watermelon is round, this rubs me up the wrong way. 
27d: the two people getting married and hence ELOPing have nothing to do with pews, only the altar and at a stretch the aisle. In fact, as they are the sole ministers of the sacrament of marriage, the furniture of a church means nothing to the validity of the sacrament. I don’t really know much about marriages in other religions, maybe they use (are they called pews?) hmm.
70a is incorrect monarch butterflies have a chrysalis, famously.
1a: what? I can imagine the sentence where this word would be used but only just, and I would rephrase it.
I don’t understand 18a at all. Is it a FB thing?
Not a huge fan of this one.

Even a brief perusal of the recent comments shows there's no need to mention that clue for 70A. Though I suppose I just did.

Got the theme before seeing the revealer, but that didn't prove helpful. Pretty easy solve, all in all.

Cute puzzle. Surely this theme has appeared before?

Loved the theme, and the mythology reference was great, but not sure how I feel about ALEPH Beth. Not once in my 22 Jewish years on this earth have I ever pronounced, or heard anyone pronounce, Bet as Beth
I hated this one.

Check out Emily Wilson’s recent translation of the Odyssey if you want to brush up on the classic source material- its fresh and very readable (not stuffy) and it conveys the sense of wonder that you’re looking for in Greek mythology.
I enjoyed this puzzle - probably because in my misspent youth I studied Latin and Greek :)
has anyone mentioned that monarchs butterflies emerge from chrysalises not cocoons? (70 across)

I've browsed the comments quickly, but not in detail, so I apologize in advance if this has already been raised. 

COCOON! 

OK, I know it's been pedantically hammered to death. I saw it, too. It didn't bother this biologist much, because this is a crossword, not an entomology textbook. But you do you. 

What everyone seems to have missed is that this clue/answer pair missed an awesome opportunity related to the theme. 

One of the most spectacular moths, whose pupa spins a most awesome COCOON, is...  Antheraea polyphemus, the POLYPHEMUS moth! 

During some eclosions, my home is completely covered with them at night -- I even hear their softly flapping pit-a-pats against my windows. It is a sight to behold. 

And in the morning, there might be 50 or so POLYPHEMUS clinging to the siding, the windows, and the deck -- a tiny fraction of the hordes that were present the night before. 

THAT is the sin of the 70A as clued. A much better clue would be "Wrap for 20A". That this opportunity eluded the constructor and the editors is a crime against all cruciverbalism!

Tricksy clue for 71A for a DC local. I was under the impression there is no B Street in DC's grid as the streets between A and C are Constitution Ave (north of the Capitol) and Independence Ave (south of the Capitol).

Apparently North B Street was renamed Constitution Ave in 1931 and various stretches of South B Street renamed Independence Ave between 1934 and 1950. I didn't realize, though, there's still a small stretch of South B Street (now B St SE) east of the Anacostia River.

I was all ready to complain, but the clue is technically correct even though today's B Street is very different than every other lettered street on the grid. Not sure if the technicality was intentional, but I've learned something today.

This concludes your DC geography trivia minute.
Loved the meta-theme that included the clues as well! Nicely done.

I am surprised and somewhat saddened by the people who complained about having to know something of the Hebrew alphabet. I'd have expected word-nerds to be alphabet nerds too ( and have never encountered complaints about having to know the Greek alphabet--about fraternities, yes). Check out https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphabet I had wondered how both an Indo-European language (Greek) and an Afro-Asiatic one (Hebrew) would have so many similarities in their names for the letters. Turns out BOTH took from the Phoenicians.
One time where it's ok to be naked is when you're born, but that didn't fit.
Impressive!
the pokee can't see after being poked in the eye
Thought for a brief moment on my first quick pass that we had a Wednesday rebus because there was no way potato salad was gonna fit
Georges Perec loves that.
Could we please not use the name of a murdering terrorist group as the name for a “gollee isn’t  that funny” perception? Thank you.

great fun.
speaking of chrysalides, if you happen to go to the natural history museum be sure to check out the davis family butterfly vivarium.
Love hearing Cyclops especially when X-Men 97' is out now and it's amazing!
71A. DC has A streets but no B streets which could be confused with 8
The answer to the clue "Wrap for a monarch" in this puzzle is "cocoon." But that's wrong. Moths spin cocoons and the monarch is a butterfly, which pupates in a crysalis.
Got super tripped up by "precedes Beth" not being ELIZA, haha

Not a fan

Floras is incorrect and should be florae. And then polyphemus crossing aleph and Sasha (especially when you have e_s_a) made this whole corner a giant Natick. Given the foreign words and proper names, google was the only way out. And before anyone chimes in, no, it was not possible to guess this with the crossings; this was a true Natick.

I’m posting to echo the chorus: Such a brilliant puzzle!

I wonder, concerning this puzzle’s first-submitted version, precisely how the editors responded. “Ambitious” and unconventional to be sure, but many Thursdays are. Perhaps an unclued I was just a bridge too far?

Brilliant puzzle overall, though the NW corner was an absolute bear to figure out. I don't hold a grudge when the theming is that strong, though I'd have never gotten there on my own. That's OK by me - I'm not too proud to give up a streak.

I think it may be about time for me to at last read "The Iliad" and "The Odyssey". I have such gaps in my "classics" reading, grew up reading scars and scads of science fiction short stories (and of course some non-science-fiction too), but there certainly are gaps. I know a lot of that stuff via osmosis (sirens, Cyclops, etc), and I know of the parallels between The Odyssey and "2001: A Space Odyssey" (one of my fav movies), and even to "O Brother Where Art Thou" (a delightful movie w/ a great soundtrack). And not having read them has not impeded my ability to know enough to do the appropriate crossword fill when called for… including today's, although frankly I'd never heard of "Polyphemus"! Just Cyclops. But that's why we have the crosses.

10 for the Iliad and another 10 for the Odyssey, for a total of 20.

@JB Both wrong. For the Odyssey, the time span is about 4 weeks, and perhaps for the Iliad about the same time. For the Odyssey, the story begins on the island with Calypso; the Trojan War had ended some ten years earlier. Odysseus builds a raft and 18 days later is shipwrecked on the island of the Phaeacians, a seafaring people with magical boats. They return him to Ithaka in a day or two. There Odysseus executes his revenge on the suitors. The subject of the Iliad is a dispute between Achilles and Agamemnon over a woman, a war prize. This occurs in the ninth year of the war over possibly a 3 to 4 week period; the war itself is the backdrop. Achilles refuses to fight and the Trojans, led by Hektor, are winning until Achilles gets back into the battle and eventually kills Hektor. There is no mention of the Trojan Horse, not in the Iliad.

@R2hule - you simply ha e to change your perspective:
the glyph H is read by Homer (a Greek author) as the letter called ETA.

For another thing, the letter E would be read by Homer (etc.) as the letter called EPSILON.

We get this same set of carps when a clue reads (e.g.) “What the British call a …”; the clue can be read either way equally justly:
write in the American word that is denoted by British persons saying …
OR
write in the British word that is denoted by American persons saying …

There are several trios of such words, the only examples that come to mind right now being non-emu friendly.

@Frances Hi, fellow Western Mass resident.

"Pew" is used here as a metonym, as explained in the column. 

TIL that one meaning of "metonymy" is the substitution of an adjunct for the thing meant. In this case "pews" for "church." The fact that the clue ended with "say" was a tip-off that "Eschew the pews" was not to be interpreted in the most literal way.

I got the answer immediately, but did not fully understand the precision of the clue until reading the column.

@Dayle Yes.  Actually, when a monarch caterpillar molts its 5th time what emerges is a chrysalis.  Moths also pupate and form chrysalids but first they wrap themselves in silk and pupate inside this silk cocoon.  Moth chrysalids are inside cocoons.  Butterflies have naked pupae (fun fact).  Many people are confused on this point, including Eric Carle, the author of The Very Hungry Caterpillar.

@CQ
What a great post, thanks for this. I don’t think I was aware of this moth previously, but didn’t take much research to figure out how it got its name. It has these tremendous “eye spots” on each wing. TIL these are evidently a form of distraction patterns called “startle patterns” meant to distract predators. Wiki (for what it’s worth) says, “The pattern on the hindwings of the Polyphemus moth resembles that on the head of a great horned owl.” Sure enough a quick search on YouTube yields this example of such a display.

https;//tinyurl.com/347bczda

@Dayle Another fun fact: Parnassians, which are butterflies in the swallowtail family, make cocoons, the only butterflies that do so. Also, not all moths make cocoons, such as some hawk moths, family Sphingidae, that have naked pupae. The failed monarch reference nearly ruined the puzzle for me. It would’ve been much more clever to have referenced the Polyphemus moth, Antherea polyphemus, which does make a cocoon.
